quizName: 5. Assessing the risks related to the processing of personal data
introText: You can use this test to assess your company's compliance with the obligations of a controller. After submitting your answers, you will receive a report with compiled feedback on your answers and recommended measures based on them.

questions.question: Has your company appointed a Data Protection Officer (DPO)?

choices.selectedText: You must appoint a DPO if you process sensitive data on a large scale, monitor people regularly, systematically and on a large scale, or your organisation is a public body (with the exception of the courts). It can be useful to appoint a DPO even if you are not required to do so. Read more about the appointment and duties of a DPO: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/data-protection-officers
choices.selectedActions: Great! Familiarise yourselves with the duties of a DPO in detail. You can subscribe to the Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman's newsletter for data protection officers: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/data-protection-officers

choices.selectedText: You must appoint a DPO if you process sensitive data on a large scale, monitor people regularly, systematically and on a large scale, or your organisation is a public body (with the exception of the courts). It can be useful to appoint a DPO even if you are not required to do so. Read more about the appointment and duties of a DPO: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/data-protection-officers
choices.selectedActions: Read more about the appointment and duties of a DPO. Appoint a DPO if you meet the conditions. Even if you do not appoint an official DPO, you should still designate someone in charge of data protection matters in your company. Tasks related to data protection are more likely to get done if you assign responsibility for them to specific individuals. Your company still bears the final responsibility for compliance with data protection requirements, however. You can subscribe to the Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman's newsletter for data protection officers: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/data-protection-officers

questions.guideText: A Data Protection Officer (DPO) is an internal expert who monitors the processing of personal data and helps your personnel comply with data protection regulations. Read more about the appointment and duties of a DPO: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/data-protection-officers

questions.question: Has your company implemented adequate measures to ensure the availability of personal data?

choices.selectedText:
The availability of personal data means that it is available for use when needed. The availability of personal data can be compromised by incidents such as denial-of-service attacks or ransomware.

The effectiveness of your measures taken to safeguard the availability of data should be in proportion to the potential harm caused by a disruption in availability. For example, an outage in a hospital information system can cause much more serious harm than the crashing of a hair-dresser's booking system.
choices.selectedActions: Good. You need to assess and test the adequacy of your measures on a regular basis. Instructions for improving your company's data security can be found on this page, for example: https://www.kyberturvallisuuskeskus.fi/en/ncsc-news/instructions-and-guides/instructions-and-guides-organisations-and-companies

The availability of personal data means that it is available for use when needed. The availability of personal data can be compromised by incidents such as blackouts, denial-of-service attacks or ransomware. One way of ensuring the availability of data is to make backups. The necessity and adequacy of safeguards must be assessed in relation to the conditions and risks of the processing.

The effectiveness of your measures taken to safeguard the availability of data should be in proportion to the potential harm caused by he disappearance of data or a service outage. For example, an outage in a hospital information system can cause much more serious harm to the data subject than the crashing of a hair-dresser's booking system.

questions.question: Has your company implemented adequate measures to ensure the confidentiality of personal data?

choices.selectedText:
The confidentiality of personal data means that personal data is only available to individuals authorised to access it. Confidentiality can be promoted by means such as two-factor authentication and encryption.

The necessity and adequacy of safeguards must be assessed in relation to the conditions and risks of the processing. The effectiveness of the measures taken to ensure confidentiality should be in proportion to the potential harm caused by unauthorised access to the data.
choices.selectedActions: Good. You must assess and test the adequacy of the measures on a regular basis. questions.question: How will you react if your company suspects a personal data breach?

choices.option: We have clear instructions in place for the eventuality of a personal data breach
choices.selectedText: A controller is required to prepare for possible personal data breaches by drawing up instructions. All personal data breaches, as well as their impact and the corrective measures taken as a result, must be documented regardless of the actual measures taken in response to the breach. You must be able to react to personal data breaches with a minimum of delay. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/personal-data-breaches
choices.selectedActions: Great! Make sure that the instructions take into account the obligations imposed by the GDPR with regard to the reporting and documentation of personal data breaches.

choices.option: We do not have a predefined procedure for such situations
choices.selectedText: A controller is required to prepare for possible personal data breaches by drawing up instructions. All personal data breaches, as well as their impact and the corrective measures taken as a result, must be documented regardless of the actual measures taken in response to the breach. You must be able to react to personal data breaches with a minimum of delay. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/personal-data-breaches
choices.selectedActions: Read the General Data Protection Regulation's obligations regarding personal data breaches and draw up instructions for the eventuality of a personal data breach.

choices.selectedText: A controller is required to prepare for possible personal data breaches by drawing up instructions. choices.selectedActions: Read the General Data Protection Regulation's obligations regarding personal data breaches and draw up instructions for the eventuality of a personal data breach.

questions.guideText: A personal data breach means an incident that results in the destruction, loss, alteration or unauthorised disclosure of personal data, or that grants a party not authorised to process the data access to personal data. For example, if an employee's username and password are disclosed to a third party, it is probable that they can be used to access the personal data stored by the company. Read more from the Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman's website: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/personal-data-breaches

questions.question: Has your company assessed the risks caused to the rights and freedoms of the data subjects by your processing of personal data?

choices.selectedText: The controller has an obligation to assess the risks related to the processing of personal data. The controller must assess which of the data subject's rights and liberties the processing could endanger, and what damage the data subject could suffer from the intended processing. The controller is obliged to implement all necessary measures to manage such risks and safeguard the appropriate processing of personal data. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/risk-assessment-and-data-protection-planning
choices.selectedActions: Great! You need to reassess the risks on a regular basis. If it has been a while since your last risk assessment, you should conduct a new one.

questions.question: Does the processing of personal data by your company involve one or more of the following situations? (1/3)

choices.selectedText:
It is important to identify processing situations that may involve high risk to the rights and freedoms of the data subject. The controller is required to conduct a data protection impact assessment if the intended processing is likely to cause a high risk. An impact assessment must be conducted especially when

  • new technology is used
  • criminal convictions, offences or special categories of personal data, such as health data, ethnic origin, political opinions, religious beliefs or sexual orientation, are being processed on a large scale;
  • personal aspects of individuals are assessed systematically and extensively using automated processing, and the assessment is used to make decisions that produce legal effects or similar significant effects for the individual; or
  • an area open to the public is being monitored systematically and on a large scale.
choices.selectedActions: It is possible that the processing of personal data by your company may cause high risks to the rights and freedoms of the data subject. Read more detailed examples of situations requiring an impact assessment: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/impact-assessments

questions.guideText:
It is important to identify processing situations that may involve high risk to the rights and freedoms of the data subject. The controller is required to conduct a data protection impact assessment if the intended processing is likely to cause a high risk. A data protection impact assessment is usually also needed if the processing meets two of the following criteria. The more criteria met by the processing, the more likely it is to cause a high risk to the rights and freedoms of data subjects.

  • The assessment or scoring of the data subject's work performance, financial situation, health, personal preferences, interests, reliability, behaviour, location or movements (including profiling and anticipation).
  • Decisions with legal effects or similar significant effects are being made automatically.
  • Personal data can be collected in circumstances in which the data subjects may not be aware of who is collecting their data and how the data will be used. In addition, it may be impossible for individuals to avoid being subjected to such processing in public spaces. Monitoring can refer to access control, camera surveillance or other corresponding measures.
  • This category includes, among other things, the special categories of personal data provided for in the GDPR, along with personal data concerning crimes and offences. This criterion can also cover personal documents, such as email, journals and highly personal information stored in applications intended for recording your personal life.

More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/impact-assessments

questions.guideText:
It is important to identify processing situations that may involve high risk to the rights and freedoms of the data subject. The controller is required to conduct a data protection impact assessment if the intended processing is likely to cause a high risk. A data protection impact assessment is usually also needed if the processing meets two of the following criteria. The more criteria met by the processing, the more likely it is to cause a high risk to the rights and freedoms of data subjects.

  • Assessments of scale should take into account, among other things, the number of data subjects concerned, either as an exact number or as a percentage of a group, such as the population of a town or country, the volume of the data to be processed and/or the number of individual units of data, the duration or permanence of the data processing operation, as well as the geographical scope of the processing operation.
  • Coordination or combination of data sets in a manner that is unforeseen or unexpected to the data subject. For example: A controller combines data sets originating from two or more data processing operations carried out for different purposes or by different controllers.
  • It can be difficult for the data subject to object to the processing of their data or exercise their other rights if the data subject is in a vulnerable position in relation to the controller. Vulnerable individuals refers to, for example, children, employees, patients, elderly people and asylum seekers.
  • The use of new technology can involve innovative ways of collecting and using data (such as IoT technologies), which can involve a high risk to the rights and freedoms of individuals.

More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/impact-assessments

  • Biometric data means personal data resulting from specific technical processing relating to physical, physiological or behavioural characteristics, such as facial images or dactyloscopic data, which allow or confirm the unique identification of a natural person.
  • The controller may derogate from the obligation to inform data subjects by virtue of Article 14(5)(b) of the General Data Protection Regulation. Derogation is possible if the provision of the information in question proves impossible or would involve a disproportionate effort, in particular for processing for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/derogating-from-the-rights-of-data-subjects
  • Whistleblowing systems give an organisation's staff or other parties an opportunity to report unethical conduct, practices that are contrary to the organisation's values or internal infringements anonymously. The purpose of a whistleblowing system can be to ensure adherence with an organisation's decision-making and supervision system in daily administration, for example.

questions.question: Has your company conducted a data protection impact assessment (DPIA)?

choices.selectedText: The impact assessment is designed to identify, assess and manage risks related to the processing of personal data. You are free to make a DPIA even if not obligated by the General Data Protection Regulation. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/impact-assessments
choices.selectedActions: It is good that you have conducted a DPIA. Check whether the assessment requires updating. You should also check whether the company's operations involve other processing situations that would merit an impact assessment.

choices.selectedText: The impact assessment is designed to identify, assess and manage risks related to the processing of personal data. You are free to make a DPIA even if not obligated by the General Data Protection Regulation. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/impact-assessments
choices.selectedActions: See the impact assessment instructions for when and how to conduct the DPIA. Make the impact assessment if necessary. You are welcome to use the Excel tool published on the Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman's website to make the assessment: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/impact-assessments

choices.option: We do not think that a DPIA is necessary
choices.selectedText: The impact assessment is designed to identify, assess and manage risks related to the processing of personal data. You are free to make a DPIA even if not obligated by the General Data Protection Regulation. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/impact-assessments
choices.selectedActions: You should be aware that neglecting to conduct a DPIA when required can lead to administrative sanctions, such as penalty payments and processing prohibitions. We thus recommend that controllers document why they decided not to conduct a DPIA in a specific situation. This is especially important if the situation falls in a grey area.

This report has been generated on the basis of a data protection self-assessment for SMEs at https://tietosuojaapkyrityksille.fi/en

The purpose of the report generated by the tool is to give tips and recommendations. You still need to read and understand the General Data Protection Regulation, and compliance with the report's instructions does not guarantee compliance with the GDPR. Every SME is different and requires unique data protection measures. This tool cannot replace such measures, but is only intended to support them.
